of the condensation energy $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$ ($\Delta CE

\section{Introduction.} The condensation energy (CE) $\Delta CE$ of
a superconductor is defined as the energy difference between the
normal state and the superconducting (SC) state of the same
system. The size of the CE is a measure of how much stable the SC
state is compared to the normal state, hence the CE is naturally
related to the transition temperature $T_c$. In more fundamental
context, the specific relation between the CE and the transition
temperature $T_c$ of a phase transition reveals the generic
characteristics of the phase transition. For example, a mean field
theory of the magnetic transition with local moments such as a
classic limit of Heisenberg model and Ising model has the relation
$\Delta CE_{mag} \propto T_c$ while the BCS theory of the one band
superconductor predicts $\Delta CE_{BCS} \propto T_c
^2$\cite{BCS}. These different power law relations are rooted to
the fact that the magnetic ordering above mentioned consists of
local moments, while the BCS SC ordering consists of itinerant
electrons. In more revealing aspect, the former transition is
determined solely by the potential energy (PE) gain $\Delta PE <0$
by the ordering of the local moments without kinetic energy
involved. On the other hand, the latter transition is determined
by the subtle balance between the kinetic energy (KE) loss $\Delta
KE>0$ and the potential energy gain $\Delta PE <0$ by the SC
ordering.

Therefore, the standard scaling law $\Delta CE \propto T_c ^2$ of
the BCS superconductor in fact reveals the fundamental nature of
the transition that the SC condensation is formed by itinerant
fermions. In view of this observation, the recent report by Wen
{\it et al.}\cite{CE} of $\Delta  CE \propto T_c ^{\beta}$ ($\beta
\approx 3.5$) with various Fe-based superconductors is very
intriguing and challenging to be understood. For example, a naive
extension of the above discussion leads us to speculate that {\it
the superconductivity of the Fe-based superconductors has more
itinerant nature than the standard one band BCS superconductor.}
This naive speculation is not wrong but its precise meaning needs
be clarified, as will be in this paper.

In this paper, we theoretically calculated the CE of the minimal
two band BCS model. To our surprise, we found that the relation
$\Delta CE \propto T_c ^{3}$ is a generic feature of the two band
BCS superconductor mediated by a dominant interband pairing
interaction (i.e. $|V_{inter}| > |V_{intra}|$). Our finding
implies that the observed power law relation of $\Delta CE \propto
T_c ^{3.5}$ of the Fe-based superconductors\cite{CE} is a natural
manifestation of the multiband BCS superconductor.

Finding the generic scaling power $\beta \approx 3$ of two band
BCS model with an interband pairing interaction, we have
specifically identified three causes to further increase the
scaling exponent $\beta$: (1) Increasing the strength of the {\it
inter-band} pairing interaction $V_{inter}$; this is a strong
coupling effect of increasing the ratio $\Delta_{h,e} /
\Lambda_{hi}$ ($\Lambda_{hi}$ is a BCS cut-off).

(2) Introducing a repulsive {\it intra-band} interaction
($V_{intra}
>0$); this effect is due to the competition between the KE
loss and the PE gain for the total CE. By the same token,
introducing an attractive (even very weak strength) {\it
intra-band} interaction ($V_{intra} <0$), the exponent $\beta$
quickly reduces to the standard BCS limit $\beta_{BCS}=2$.
However, increasing a {\it repulsive} $V_{intra}$, in order to
increase the scaling power $\beta$, has a limitation. Because the
repulsive $V_{intra}$ will suppress $T_c$, too, the dominance of
the {\it inter-band} interaction should be kept as $V_{inter} >
V_{intra}>0$ in order to maintain a SC transition.

(3) Pair-breaking impurity scattering also increases $\beta$; this
is not an intrinsic property of the two band BCS model but an
extrinsic effect. This effect is because of the fact that the
pair-breaking impurity scattering is more efficient to reduce
$\Delta_{h,e}$ than to suppress $T_c$ which will be explained
later.

The observed power $\beta \sim 3.5$ \cite{CE} may very well be due
to the combination of all of these three causes.

Our finding can have a more illuminating implication in more
general context. Although there are abundant experimental probes
to identify the SC gap symmetry, there exists almost no direct
probe for the pairing mechanism itself. This is the main reason
why the progress of understanding the pairing mechanism of the
unconventional superconductors has been hampered in the last three
decades. For example, the isotope effect measurement\cite{isotope}
with the phonon mediated superconductors is considered as the
concluding experiment for identifying the BCS pairing mechanism,
at least conceptually. However, after early successful
measurements in accord with the theoretical prediction of the
isotope effect coefficient $\alpha=0.5$\cite{MA}, there have been
numerous reports of large deviations even with the low-$T_c$,
phonon mediated superconductors\cite{exception}. Therefore, in
retrospect, it is uncertain if the isotope coefficient measurement
can be really a smoking-gun experiment for the phonon pairing
mechanism.

In this sense, our finding shows that the scaling relation $\Delta
CE \propto T_c ^{\beta} (\beta \approx 3)$ of the multiband
superconductors is another rare example of the theoretical
prediction for identifying the pairing mechanism which is
experimentally testable.

Although we cannot completely rule out other alternative theories,
our successful explanation for the anomalous CE scaling relation,
combined with the recent successful explanation\cite{SH_jump} of
the another anomalous scaling of the specific heat jump $\Delta C$
{\it vs.} $T_c$ (BNC scaling $\Delta C \sim T_c^3$\cite{BNC,
JSKim, Hardy, Gofryk}) using the same model, provides a convincing
evidence that {\it the pairing mechanism of the Fe-based
superconductors is genuinely a BCS theory, operating with the
multiband system.} The strong correlation effects certainly exist
in these compounds and should renormalize the quasiparticle masses
$m_{qp}^{*}$ and the pairing interactions $V(\bf q)$. However,
after these renormalizations, the SC pairing process itself seems
to be governed by the BCS pairing mechanism.

\subsection{Modelling of doping}
To make a direct comparison with the experimental data of $\Delta
CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$ for the Fe-based superconductors\cite{CE},
which are the collection of data of various iron pnictide and
chalcogenide (FePn/Ch) SC compounds with systematic dopings by
holes or electrons, we need a modelling of doping. Specifically,
we are modelling the cases of (Ba$_{1-x}$K$_x$)Fe$_2$As$_2$ and
Ba(Fe$_{1-x}$Co$_x$)$_2$As$_2$ which have the most systematic
dopings in the experimental data.

We first note that the undoped parent compound BaFe$_2$As$_2$ is a
compensated metal, hence has the same number of electrons and
holes, i.e. $n_h = n_e$. Therefore it is a reasonable
approximation to assume $N_h = N_e$ at no doping and then the
doping of holes (K, Na, etc.) or electrons (Co, Ni, etc.) is
simulated by varying $N_h$ and $N_e$ while keeping $N_e + N_h
=N_{tot} = const.$ Admittedly this modelling of doping is much too
simple. However this assumption is qualitatively consistent with
the Angle-Resolved-Photo-Emission-Spectroscopy (ARPES)
measurements of (Ba$_{1-x}$K$_x$)Fe$_2$As$_2$\cite{Sato} and
Ba(Fe$_{1-x}$Co$_x$)$_2$As$_2$\cite{Sudayama} which show the
systematic changes of hole (electron) FS sizes with dopings.
Furthermore, the assumption $N_{tot} = const.$ is only for
convenience and can be relaxed. The sensitive parameters of our
model are the relative sizes between $N_e$ and $N_h$ but not the
total DOS $N_{tot}$. Finally, it is not necessary to know the
exact relation between the actual doping concentration $"x"$ of
real compounds and the values of $N_{h(e)}$ in our two-band model.
When we plot our calculation results of $\Delta CE(N_{h(e)})$ {\it
vs.} $T_c (N_{h(e)})$, the values of $N_{h(e)}$ are hidden
parameters and we only compare the scaling relation of $\Delta CE
\sim T_c^{\beta}$ with the experimental data.

\section{Numerical results}

In all our numerical calculations, we only considered the
sign-changing s-wave ($s_{\pm}$) gap solutions assuming a
repulsive {\it inter-band} interaction ($V_{inter} >0$). Also
notice that all energy scales in this paper are normalized by
$N_{tot}$ such as $\bar{V}_{ab}=N_{tot}V_{ab}$ and
$\bar{N}_{h,e}=N_{h,e}/N_{tot}$. For given pairing interactions
$\bar{V}_{inter, intra}$, we solve the coupled gap equation Eq.(9)
with the mean field Hamiltonian Eq.(8) for continuously varying
$\bar{N}_h ~(\bar{N}_e=1-\bar{N}_h)$. In the $T \rightarrow 0$
limit, we obtain $\Delta_{h,e}$ and $b_{h,e}$ with which we
calculate $\Delta CE$. $T_c$ can be calculated by taking
$\Delta_{h,e} \rightarrow 0$ limit. $\Delta CE$ is always negative
($<0$) by definition but we plot its absolute values in all
figures.

In Fig.1, we studied the case of the pure inter-band pairing case
(B): $\bar{V}_{intra}=\bar{V}_{ee}=\bar{V}_{hh}=0$. We plotted
$\Delta CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$ for
$\bar{V}_{inter}(=\bar{V}_{he}=\bar{V}_{eh})=1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0,$
and $5.0$, respectively. To our surprise, this simple model
produces a strongly non-BCS power law scaling $\Delta CE \sim
T_c^{\beta}~ (\beta=2.7-3)$ for a wide range of $T_c$ and $\Delta
CE$ varies over three orders of magnitude. This is exactly the key
feature of the experimental data. Considering the extreme
simplicity of our two band model, we believe that this two-band
model captures the essential ingredients of the pairing mechanism
of the Fe-based superconductors, that is, {\it a multi-band BCS
superconductor mediated by a dominant repulsive inter-band pairing
interaction.} In fact, the results of Fig.1 can be reproduced
exactly the same if we use an attractive inter-band pairing
interaction ($\bar{V}_{inter} < 0$) with the $s_{++}$-wave gap
solution ($sign(\Delta_h)=sign(\Delta_e)$). However, we will find
a consistent evidence to choose $\bar{V}_{inter} > 0$ when we
consider the effect of the intra-band interaction
$\bar{V}_{intra}\neq 0$ in Fig.2.

Scrutinizing more details of Fig.1, we observe: (1) Increasing the
strength of $\bar{V}_{inter}$, the scaling power $\beta$ gradually
increases. (2) However, even the steepest power ($\beta\sim 3$)
for $\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$ in Fig.1 is still weaker than the
experimental observation $\beta_{exp} \sim 3.5$\cite{CE}. With
$\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$, the dimensionless coupling constant
$\lambda=\bar{V}_{inter}\sqrt{\bar{N}_h \bar{N}_e} \leq 2.5$ since
$\lambda^{Max}=5.0 \sqrt{0.5 \cdot 0.5}=2.5$ with
$\bar{N}_{h,e}=N_{h,e}/N_{tot}$. Therefore, although
$\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$ is a strong coupling, it is not a totally
unrealistic limit.

As discussed with Eq.(15), when $\bar{V}_{intra}=0$, the
expression of the total CE $\Delta CE$ appears as a sum of two
single band BCS CE. Nevertheless, the result of Fig.1 shows that
it doesn't follow the standard BCS scaling law $\Delta CE \sim T_c
^2$ with $N_{tot}=const.$, but follows much stronger power law
$\Delta CE \sim T_c ^{\beta}$ with $\beta\approx 3$. As we
mentioned earlier, the origin of this strong power law is because
of the combined effect of the peculiar inverse relation of
$\frac{|\Delta_h|}{|\Delta_e|} \sim \frac{N_e}{N_h}$ and the
$T_c$-equation $T_c \sim \exp[-1/(V_{inter}\sqrt{N_hN_e})]$ of the
two band model in the pure inter-band pairing limit
\cite{SH_jump}.

In Fig.2, we studied the effect of the intra-band interaction
$\bar{V}_{intra} \neq 0$.  We experimented both repulsive
($\bar{V}_{intra}
> 0$) and attractive ($\bar{V}_{intra} < 0$) intra-band
interactions while fixing a moderate strength of repulsive
inter-band interaction $\bar{V}_{inter}=2.0$. First, when we add
an attractive ($\bar{V}_{intra} < 0$) intra-band interaction, we
found: (1) $T_c$ quickly increases and the distribution of $T_c$s
for varying $\bar{N}_h$ shrinks to the narrow range (see open pink
stars for $\bar{V}_{intra}=-1.0$ and black solid squares for
$\bar{V}_{intra}=-0.5$). (2) The scaling relation quickly
converges to the BCS limit $\Delta CE \sim T_c^2$; even a very
weak attractive intra-band interaction $\bar{V}_{intra}=-0.5$
(black solid squares) is sufficient to make it. On the other hand,
when a repulsive intra-band interaction ($\bar{V}_{intra} >0$) is
added, the opposite trend occurs. Namely the scaling relation
becomes steeper, in particular, more effective near the higher
$T_c$ region. For example, when $\bar{V}_{intra} = +1.0$, $\beta$
becomes almost 3 (compare with the case $\bar{V}_{intra}=0.0$
which has $\beta \sim 2.7$). However, we cannot keep increasing a
repulsive $\bar{V}_{intra}$ which would kill superconductivity (
$T_c \rightarrow 0$) when $\bar{V}_{intra} > \bar{V}_{inter}$. In
comparison with the experimental data\cite{CE}, this numerical
experiment of repulsive and attractive intra-band interactions
($\bar{V}_{intra}
>$ or $< 0$) in Fig.2 reveals a convincing evidence that the
intra-band interaction in the Fe-based superconductors should be
repulsive ($\bar{V}_{intra} > 0$) -- at least, not attractive.









Finally, in Fig.3, we studied the effect of the pair-breaking
impurity scattering $\Gamma_{\pi}$\cite{SH_jump}. We have also
studied the non-pair-breaking impurity scattering $\Gamma_{0}$ and
found that it has no effect on the scaling which is understandable
with Anderson theorem. The results in Fig.3 shows the general
trend that the scaling relation of $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$
becomes steeper with increasing the pair-breaking impurity
scattering rate $\Gamma_{\pi}$. A very weak impurity scattering
rate $\Gamma_{\pi}/\Lambda_{hi}=0.05$ is already enough to make
the scaling as $\Delta CE \sim T_c^{3.5}$ as consistent with the
experimental data\cite{CE}.

The increasing of the scaling power with the impurity scattering
shown in Fig.3 is due to the fact that the pair-breaking impurity
scattering more efficiently reduces $\Delta CE$ than $T_c$.
Technical reason for this phenomena is due to the multiple
scattering process in the $\mathcal{T}$-matrix of the impurity
scattering which we used in our calculations\cite{Bang_imp,
SH_jump}. This $\mathcal{T}$-matrix represents the final impurity
scattering effect including a certain many body process. The
$\Delta CE$-reduction is affected by the $\mathcal{T}(T)$ at $T=0$
and the $T_c$-suppression is affected by the $\mathcal{T}(T)$ at
$T=T_c$. It turns out that $\mathcal{T}(T=0)$ is always larger
than $\mathcal{T}(T=T_c)$ due to the resonance effect when the SC
gaps open ($\Delta_{h,e} \neq 0$). Hence, the pair-breaking
impurity scattering becomes slightly more efficient for the
$\Delta CE$-reduction than for the $T_c$-suppression. And this
discrepancy of the impurity effects is systematically more
enhanced as $T_c$ decreases. As a result of all these effects,
Fig.3 shows that the low $T_c$ tail of the $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.}
$T_c$ scaling becomes rapidly steeper with impurity scattering.

\section{Mechanism determining the scaling power $\beta$}
In Fig.2, we numerically found that the repulsive (attractive)
intra-band interactions increases (decreases) the scaling power
$\beta$. We would like to discuss this effect of the intra-band
interaction, $\bar{V}_{intra}
>$ or $< 0$, on the scaling power $\beta$ in more general context. In
the introduction, we pointed out that the PE only transition such
as insulating magnets has $\Delta CE \sim T_c$ while the BCS
superconductor, which develops the transition by a subtle balance
between the $\Delta PE$ and $\Delta KE$ (the $\Delta KE$ always
opposes to the ordering transition\cite{NFL}), has $\Delta CE \sim
T_c^2$. This balance between the $\Delta KE$ loss ($>0$) and the
$\Delta PE$ gain ($<0$) is the generic feature of the ordering
transitions of the itinerant fermion system such as SC and density
wave (DW) ordering. In this view, the higher power scaling
relation $\Delta E \sim T_c^{3.5}$ observed with the Fe-based
superconductors\cite{CE} implies that the Fe-based
superconductivity should be either (1) suffering more KE loss, or
(2) not sufficiently harvesting the PE gain through its
transition. Both cases are not good news for us wishing to gain
the maximum possible CE in order to increase $T_c$. We will show
below that the cause (2) is the fundamental origin of the steep
scaling relation ($\Delta CE \sim T_c^{3.5}$) of the Fe-based
superconductors.

In Fig.4, we illustrate this energetic balance of the multi-band
SC systems. We want to emphasize that, in the illustrations of
Fig.4, we considered all {\it"attractive" inter-band} interactions
($V_{inter} <0$, red color) assuming the $\Delta_{++}$ gap
solution in order to systematically illustrate the continuous
evolution starting from the single band BCS superconductor to
multi-band systems. However, all discussions and conclusions of
the two band cases in Fig.4(b), Fig.4(c), and Fig.4(d) --which is
our main interest -- remain unchanged if we replace an {\it
"attractive" inter-band} interactions ($V_{inter} <0$) by a {\it
"repulsive" inter-band} interactions ($V_{inter} >0$) with
replacing the $\Delta_{++}$ by the $\Delta_{\pm}$ gap solution.
The effect of the intra-band interactions $V_{intra}$ with their
signs remains unchanged regardless of the choice of the sign of
$V_{inter}$ and its corresponding gap solutions because the
intra-band interactions do not see the other band.

\section{Summary and Conclusions}
We have studied the scaling relation of the $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.}
$T_c$ of the two band BCS model. The doping (either holes or
electrons) in the real compounds was modelled by continuously
varying the hole ($N_h$) and electron ($N_e$) DOSs keeping the
total DOS $N_{tot}=const.$ With numerical calculations, we found
that (1) $\Delta CE \sim T_c^{\beta}$ with $\beta\approx 3$ is a
generic and intrinsic feature of the two band BCS superconductor
mediated by a dominant inter-band pairing interaction (either
attractive or repulsive). (2) A repulsive intra-band interaction
can increase the scaling power $\beta$, but still weaker than the
experimental observation $\beta_{exp}\approx 3.5$\cite{CE}. On the
other hand, an attractive intra-band interaction -- even if very
weak -- immediately turns the scaling relation into a BCS limit
$\Delta CE \sim T_c^2$, therefore we are forced to rule out a
possible attractive intra-band interaction in real compounds.
Considering the physical constraint of the general pairing
potential $V(\bf q)$ (either uniformly $>0$ or $<0$), we conclude
that the both intra- and inter-band interactions should be
repulsive leading to the $\Delta_{\pm}$ gap solution. (3) Adding a
small amount of pair-breaking impurity scattering
($\Gamma_{\pi}=0.05\Lambda_{hi}$) can easily increase $\beta$
close to the experimental value of $\beta_{exp}\approx 3.5$.

We have also illustrated that the general principle determining
the scaling relation $\Delta CE \sim T_c^{\beta}$ is the balance
between the KE loss and the PE gain through the SC transition. The
stronger scaling relation of $\Delta CE \sim T_c^{\beta}$
($\beta\approx 3.5$), observed in a large number of the Fe-based
superconductors, than the standard BCS scaling of $\beta_{BCS}=2$
is due to the fact that the Fe-based superconductors, being a
multi-band BCS superconductor, cannot fully harvest all possible
PE gain because of the repulsive intra-band interaction.

Most importantly, our study has made a strong case that the
experimentally observed seemingly non-BCS scaling relation of
$\Delta CE \sim T_c^{3.5}$\cite{CE} is in fact a strong evidence
that the Fe-based superconductors are the BCS superconductors, but
with multi-bands, mediated by a dominant repulsive inter-band
pairing interaction. All strong correlation effects, abundantly
observed in the normal state, should renormalize the effective
mass $m_{qp}^{*}$ of quasiparticles and the pairing interactions
$V_{inter,intra}(\bf q)$, etc., but when the system enters the SC
transition, the pairing mechanism itself seems to be governed by
the BCS mechanism. Our study, being a mean field theory, didn't
include the effects of the strong coupling theory of
superconductivity such as Eliashberg theory. While some minor
corrections are possible with such a dynamic theory, we think that
the basic energetics (the KE loss and the PE gain) of the BCS
superconductors, which determines the scaling relation of the CE
{\it vs.} $T_c$, should be generic and robust.

Finally, the discussions and conclusions of this paper should not
have direct relevance with the FeSe monolayer and related systems
where only electron FSs exist\cite{FeSe}.

\subsection{Modelling of doping}
To make a direct comparison with the experimental data of $\Delta
CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$ for the Fe-based superconductors\cite{CE},
which are the collection of data of various iron pnictide and
chalcogenide (FePn/Ch) SC compounds with systematic dopings by
holes or electrons, we need a modelling of doping. Specifically,
we are modelling the cases of (Ba$_{1-x}$K$_x$)Fe$_2$As$_2$ and
Ba(Fe$_{1-x}$Co$_x$)$_2$As$_2$ which have the most systematic
dopings in the experimental data.

We first note that the undoped parent compound BaFe$_2$As$_2$ is a
compensated metal, hence has the same number of electrons and
holes, i.e. $n_h = n_e$. Therefore it is a reasonable
approximation to assume $N_h = N_e$ at no doping and then the
doping of holes (K, Na, etc.) or electrons (Co, Ni, etc.) is
simulated by varying $N_h$ and $N_e$ while keeping $N_e + N_h
=N_{tot} = const.$ Admittedly this modelling of doping is much too
simple. However this assumption is qualitatively consistent with
the Angle-Resolved-Photo-Emission-Spectroscopy (ARPES)
measurements of (Ba$_{1-x}$K$_x$)Fe$_2$As$_2$\cite{Sato} and
Ba(Fe$_{1-x}$Co$_x$)$_2$As$_2$\cite{Sudayama} which show the
systematic changes of hole (electron) FS sizes with dopings.
Furthermore, the assumption $N_{tot} = const.$ is only for
convenience and can be relaxed. The sensitive parameters of our
model are the relative sizes between $N_e$ and $N_h$ but not the
total DOS $N_{tot}$. Finally, it is not necessary to know the
exact relation between the actual doping concentration $"x"$ of
real compounds and the values of $N_{h(e)}$ in our two-band model.
When we plot our calculation results of $\Delta CE(N_{h(e)})$ {\it
vs.} $T_c (N_{h(e)})$, the values of $N_{h(e)}$ are hidden
parameters and we only compare the scaling relation of $\Delta CE
\sim T_c^{\beta}$ with the experimental data.

\section{Numerical results}

In all our numerical calculations, we only considered the
sign-changing s-wave ($s_{\pm}$) gap solutions assuming a
repulsive {\it inter-band} interaction ($V_{inter} >0$). Also
notice that all energy scales in this paper are normalized by
$N_{tot}$ such as $\bar{V}_{ab}=N_{tot}V_{ab}$ and
$\bar{N}_{h,e}=N_{h,e}/N_{tot}$. For given pairing interactions
$\bar{V}_{inter, intra}$, we solve the coupled gap equation Eq.(9)
with the mean field Hamiltonian Eq.(8) for continuously varying
$\bar{N}_h ~(\bar{N}_e=1-\bar{N}_h)$. In the $T \rightarrow 0$
limit, we obtain $\Delta_{h,e}$ and $b_{h,e}$ with which we
calculate $\Delta CE$. $T_c$ can be calculated by taking
$\Delta_{h,e} \rightarrow 0$ limit. $\Delta CE$ is always negative
($<0$) by definition but we plot its absolute values in all
figures.

In Fig.1, we studied the case of the pure inter-band pairing case
(B): $\bar{V}_{intra}=\bar{V}_{ee}=\bar{V}_{hh}=0$. We plotted
$\Delta CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$ for
$\bar{V}_{inter}(=\bar{V}_{he}=\bar{V}_{eh})=1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0,$
and $5.0$, respectively. To our surprise, this simple model
produces a strongly non-BCS power law scaling $\Delta CE \sim
T_c^{\beta}~ (\beta=2.7-3)$ for a wide range of $T_c$ and $\Delta
CE$ varies over three orders of magnitude. This is exactly the key
feature of the experimental data. Considering the extreme
simplicity of our two band model, we believe that this two-band
model captures the essential ingredients of the pairing mechanism
of the Fe-based superconductors, that is, {\it a multi-band BCS
superconductor mediated by a dominant repulsive inter-band pairing
interaction.} In fact, the results of Fig.1 can be reproduced
exactly the same if we use an attractive inter-band pairing
interaction ($\bar{V}_{inter} < 0$) with the $s_{++}$-wave gap
solution ($sign(\Delta_h)=sign(\Delta_e)$). However, we will find
a consistent evidence to choose $\bar{V}_{inter} > 0$ when we
consider the effect of the intra-band interaction
$\bar{V}_{intra}\neq 0$ in Fig.2.

Scrutinizing more details of Fig.1, we observe: (1) Increasing the
strength of $\bar{V}_{inter}$, the scaling power $\beta$ gradually
increases. (2) However, even the steepest power ($\beta\sim 3$)
for $\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$ in Fig.1 is still weaker than the
experimental observation $\beta_{exp} \sim 3.5$\cite{CE}. With
$\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$, the dimensionless coupling constant
$\lambda=\bar{V}_{inter}\sqrt{\bar{N}_h \bar{N}_e} \leq 2.5$ since
$\lambda^{Max}=5.0 \sqrt{0.5 \cdot 0.5}=2.5$ with
$\bar{N}_{h,e}=N_{h,e}/N_{tot}$. Therefore, although
$\bar{V}_{inter}=5.0$ is a strong coupling, it is not a totally
unrealistic limit.

As discussed with Eq.(15), when $\bar{V}_{intra}=0$, the
expression of the total CE $\Delta CE$ appears as a sum of two
single band BCS CE. Nevertheless, the result of Fig.1 shows that
it doesn't follow the standard BCS scaling law $\Delta CE \sim T_c
^2$ with $N_{tot}=const.$, but follows much stronger power law
$\Delta CE \sim T_c ^{\beta}$ with $\beta\approx 3$. As we
mentioned earlier, the origin of this strong power law is because
of the combined effect of the peculiar inverse relation of
$\frac{|\Delta_h|}{|\Delta_e|} \sim \frac{N_e}{N_h}$ and the
$T_c$-equation $T_c \sim \exp[-1/(V_{inter}\sqrt{N_hN_e})]$ of the
two band model in the pure inter-band pairing limit
\cite{SH_jump}.

In Fig.2, we studied the effect of the intra-band interaction
$\bar{V}_{intra} \neq 0$.  We experimented both repulsive
($\bar{V}_{intra}

interactions while fixing a moderate strength of repulsive
inter-band interaction $\bar{V}_{inter}=2.0$. First, when we add
an attractive ($\bar{V}_{intra} < 0$) intra-band interaction, we
found: (1) $T_c$ quickly increases and the distribution of $T_c$s
for varying $\bar{N}_h$ shrinks to the narrow range (see open pink
stars for $\bar{V}_{intra}=-1.0$ and black solid squares for
$\bar{V}_{intra}=-0.5$). (2) The scaling relation quickly
converges to the BCS limit $\Delta CE \sim T_c^2$; even a very
weak attractive intra-band interaction $\bar{V}_{intra}=-0.5$
(black solid squares) is sufficient to make it. On the other hand,
when a repulsive intra-band interaction ($\bar{V}_{intra} >0$) is
added, the opposite trend occurs. Namely the scaling relation
becomes steeper, in particular, more effective near the higher
$T_c$ region. For example, when $\bar{V}_{intra} = +1.0$, $\beta$
becomes almost 3 (compare with the case $\bar{V}_{intra}=0.0$
which has $\beta \sim 2.7$). However, we cannot keep increasing a
repulsive $\bar{V}_{intra}$ which would kill superconductivity (
$T_c \rightarrow 0$) when $\bar{V}_{intra} > \bar{V}_{inter}$. In
comparison with the experimental data\cite{CE}, this numerical
experiment of repulsive and attractive intra-band interactions
($\bar{V}_{intra}
>$ or $< 0$) in Fig.2 reveals a convincing evidence that the
intra-band interaction in the Fe-based superconductors should be
repulsive ($\bar{V}_{intra} > 0$) -- at least, not attractive.









Finally, in Fig.3, we studied the effect of the pair-breaking
impurity scattering $\Gamma_{\pi}$\cite{SH_jump}. We have also
studied the non-pair-breaking impurity scattering $\Gamma_{0}$ and
found that it has no effect on the scaling which is understandable
with Anderson theorem. The results in Fig.3 shows the general
trend that the scaling relation of $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.} $T_c$
becomes steeper with increasing the pair-breaking impurity
scattering rate $\Gamma_{\pi}$. A very weak impurity scattering
rate $\Gamma_{\pi}/\Lambda_{hi}=0.05$ is already enough to make
the scaling as $\Delta CE \sim T_c^{3.5}$ as consistent with the
experimental data\cite{CE}.

The increasing of the scaling power with the impurity scattering
shown in Fig.3 is due to the fact that the pair-breaking impurity
scattering more efficiently reduces $\Delta CE$ than $T_c$.
Technical reason for this phenomena is due to the multiple
scattering process in the $\mathcal{T}$-matrix of the impurity
scattering which we used in our calculations\cite{Bang_imp,
SH_jump}. This $\mathcal{T}$-matrix represents the final impurity
scattering effect including a certain many body process. The
$\Delta CE$-reduction is affected by the $\mathcal{T}(T)$ at $T=0$
and the $T_c$-suppression is affected by the $\mathcal{T}(T)$ at
$T=T_c$. It turns out that $\mathcal{T}(T=0)$ is always larger
than $\mathcal{T}(T=T_c)$ due to the resonance effect when the SC
gaps open ($\Delta_{h,e} \neq 0$). Hence, the pair-breaking
impurity scattering becomes slightly more efficient for the
$\Delta CE$-reduction than for the $T_c$-suppression. And this
discrepancy of the impurity effects is systematically more
enhanced as $T_c$ decreases. As a result of all these effects,
Fig.3 shows that the low $T_c$ tail of the $\Delta CE$ {\it vs.}
$T_c$ scaling becomes rapidly steeper with impurity scattering.

\section{Mechanism determining the scaling power $\beta$}
In Fig.2, we numerically found that the repulsive (attractive)
intra-band interactions increases (decreases) the scaling power
$\beta$. We would like to discuss this effect of the intra-band
interaction, $\bar{V}_{intra}
>$ or $< 0$, on the scaling power $\beta$ in more general context. In
the introduction, we pointed out that the PE only transition such
as insulating magnets has $\Delta CE \sim T_c$ while the BCS
superconductor, which develops the transition by a subtle balance
between the $\Delta PE$ and $\Delta KE$ (the $\Delta KE$ always
opposes to the ordering transition\cite{NFL}), has $\Delta CE \sim
T_c^2$. This balance between the $\Delta KE$ loss ($>0$) and the
$\Delta PE$ gain ($<0$) is the generic feature of the ordering
transitions of the itinerant fermion system such as SC and density
wave (DW) ordering. In this view, the higher power scaling
relation $\Delta E \sim T_c^{3.5}$ observed with the Fe-based
superconductors\cite{CE} implies that the Fe-based
superconductivity should be either (1) suffering more KE loss, or
(2) not sufficiently harvesting the PE gain through its
transition. Both cases are not good news for us wishing to gain
the maximum possible CE in order to increase $T_c$. We will show
below that the cause (2) is the fundamental origin of the steep
scaling relation ($\Delta CE \sim T_c^{3.5}$) of the Fe-based
superconductors.

SC systems. We want to emphasize that, in the illustrations of

"attractive" inter-band} interactions ($V_{inter} <0$) by a {\it

signs remains unchanged regardless of the choice of the sign of

intra-band interactions do not see the other band.
